status_message:
In 2015, Riverside voters rejected a ballot measure that would have allowed about 10 medical marijuana dispensaries to open in the city. But last November, they said yes to Prop. 64, which legalized adult use of the drug.

Did you vote in both elections, and if so, did you change your mind? Or do you live in a household where people voted differently on the issue? With marijuana now legal statewide, should Riverside allow, tax and regulate pot shops, or continue its ban?

If you'd like to be interviewed, call reporter Alicia Robinson at 951-368-9461.

This isn't how Donald Trump imagined closing the biggest deal of his life.

Instead of triumphantly addressing California's GOP convention this weekend with his enemies silenced and his sights on Hillary Clinton, he is now hunkering down to spend the next several weeks in the Golden State  usually an afterthought in presidential politics  fighting a series of bloody battles with John Kasich and Ted Cruz, congressional district by congressional district.

status_message:
Dikymbe Martin left a lasting legacy during his time with the Riverside North boys basketball team. A four-year starter, Martin led the Huskies to 110 victories, four league titles and a pair of section championships. For this Martin has been selected the HSGameTime Boys Basketball Player of the Year.

And he'll remain the pride of Riverside, as he'll take his all-around skills down the street to UC Riverside.
Find out more about Martin -- and other All-Area players -- here: http://www.pe.com/articles/boys-799691-year-girls.html

status_message:
Moreno Valley city and school officials again are debating who should pay for crossing guards, and it's not clear if the two sides have reached an agreement.

A city report going to council members Tuesday states that city and school officials have a tentative pact to share costs, with each paying $380,000 a year starting this fall.

The plan also calls for program cuts  eliminating crossing guards at five locations and during midday  and suggests contracting out instead of using city employees for future savings. Crossing guards would remain at 22 other locations, the report states.

What do you think of this plan? Will it cause more problems than helping?
link_name: MORENO VALLEY: Is there a deal to share crossing guard costs?

status_message:
On Thursday, April 14, a court decision reversed a judge's ruling that found teacher tenure deprived students of a good education. It was a win for teachers' unions, but is likely to be appealed.

Inland educators and others are split on tenure. Teachers say they deserve and have earned the right and that experience means a lot at the front of the classroom. Others say the system protects bad teachers and can lead to poor educations for minority and low-income students.

What do you think about teacher tenure?
link_name: Ruling backing teacher tenure is praised, criticized

Breaking news: Southern California children are breathing much easier today than two decades ago, according to a USC medical school study that credited the gain to steady reductions in air pollution.

Researchers found that asthmatic and non-asthmatic children now are much less likely to suffer from cold-like symptoms. Air pollution levels have dropped by as much as half since the early 1990s.

The office of California Attorney General Kamala Harris announced Wednesday evening that it had won a $1.1 billion judgment against now defunct Corinthian Colleges, Inc.

The Orange County-based company had operated Everest College locations in San Bernardino and Ontario before being hit with a $30 million dollar fee in April 2015 from the Department of Education for abusive practices. It then declared bankruptcy and closed its campuses.

Wanted: at least 427 volunteers to shimmy their hips at the San Bernardino County Museum in Redlands on April 2 to break a Guinness World Record for the largest "Soul Train" line ever. No experience in line dancing, the Locomotion, Cha Cha Slide or Electric Slide is required. But guests can dust off their old bell bottoms, Afro wigs, floral-print shirts and peace-sign spectacles.

The race for the 31st Congressional District in San Bernardino County is heating up. They won't be doing it that way anymore. Find out about the changes being made in staffing and procedures: http://www.pe.com/articles/city-797493-council-budget.html and share your thoughts on what happened.

About 150 members of the United Nurses Association of California/Union of Health Care Professionals, clad in blue T-shirts, stood on the steps of Corona City Hall to protest the deunionization of Corona Regional Medical Center nurses, and to advocate the union to ensure patient care. BREAKING: 2 arrested as suspects in White Park shooting.

Two people have been arrested in connection with a shooting at White Park in downtown Riverside that hospitalized a man on Monday, Feb. 29, Riverside police officials say.

Cory Chenno James, 26, of Riverside and Leshawn Karisha Johnson, 25, of Colton were both arrested during a traffic stop in Colton on Tuesday, March 1, according to a Riverside police news release.

They were later arrested on suspicion of attempted murder and booked at Robert Presley Detention Center after police interviewed them, the release says.
link_name: RIVERSIDE: 2 arrested in connection with White Park shooting

status_message:
Apple said in court papers Thursday, Feb. 25 that a judge's order for the electronics company to aid the FBI with specially created software to see the data inside an iPhone used by one of the terrorists in the San Bernardino shooting is about the government "seeking through the courts a dangerous power."

Apple says the U.S. Department of Justice and the FBI want "the ability to force companies like Apple to undermine the basic security and privacy interests of hundreds of millions of individuals around the globe."

The motion by Apple seeks U.S. Magistrate Judge Sheri Pym to both vacate the order and deny the subsequent government motion to compel.
link_name: SAN BERNARDINO SHOOTING: Apple asks court to withdraw order to help FBI get data

status_message:
Three San Bernardino County sheriff's deputies who beat and kicked a man they arrested after a three-hour pursuit across the High Desert last year will face trial on a felony charge of assault by a peace officer, a judge ruled Monday.

Deputies Charles Foster, Michael Phelps and Nick Downey "breached the public trust," the prosecutor told Judge Katrina West during a preliminary hearing that focused on a video of Francis Jared Pusok's April 2015 arrest shot by a KNBC-4 news helicopter.

The deputies' defense attorneys contended that no crime was committed because Pusok's actions before and during the arrest, and the danger they believed he posed, justified the amount of force deputies used.
link_name: VIDEOTAPED BEATING: Deputies to have preliminary hearing Monday morning

status_message:
Moreno Valley resident Gary Orvis, a veteran of the first Gulf War, is partially disabled and suffers from hearing loss, panic attacks, Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder and Gulf War Syndrome.
On Saturday, he'll get a source of support in the form of Dreamy, a service dog provided by a local nonprofit organization called Rebuilding Warriors.

Service animals play an important role in helping soldiers heal from battle injuries such as Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder, brain injuries and amputations. The dogs also assist veterans who have problems with their balance due to a brain injury.

What do you think of this program? Do you know anyone who has participated?
link_name: Service dogs offer veterans support

status_message:
As the Beaumont City Council was hearing a midyear budget review, Councilman Lloyd White held up a four-page report from January 2014 that said finances were fine.

Anyone who has followed the city since knows what he was referring to. Not only were finances not fine, the city was actually in deep financial trouble thanks to poor bookkeeping and potentially questionable relationships with consultants. The city is facing a state audit and other inquiries into its practices.

But when the city's finance director on Tuesday, Feb. 16, said things are looking up, she had the information to back that up. For the first time in memory, budgets have been itemized, Onyx Jones said. And the city's $29 million spending plan remains balanced, even after adjustments were made.
link_name: BEAUMONT: Budget outlook brightens for cash-strapped city

status_message:
Driving north from Baker toward Death Valley National Park, one can't miss the distinctive Dumont Dunes. The sprawling mountains of golden sand are visible for miles as the highway weaves around them and the Amargosa River, a normally dry stream that has been running thanks to winter storms.

The tallest dune, Competition Hill, rises 500 feet above a surreal landscape that looks like a setting in a "Star Wars" movie.
In a recreation-loving region where off-roading is huge, the 8,150-acre Dumont Dunes is small when stacked up against the Imperial Sand Dunes Recreation Area, which is popularly known as Glamis.

Have you been to Dumont Dunes? When is the best time of year to go?
link_name: DUMONT DUNES: Tiny spot on map is huge with off-roaders

status_message:
A U.S. House member who represents the bulk of Temecula, Rep. Duncan Hunter, caused a bit of stir on the hill Thursday by vaping during a hearing.

Hunter broke out his vaporizer pen, which he has said he uses in lieu of tobacco products, to illustrate how harmless the activity is during a conversation about use of the devices on airplanes.

In a video that has been posted on political and pop culture websites, Hunter can be seen puffing from the pen and blowing out a cloud of vapor.

He goes on to say that vaporizer devices eventually will be used to deliver other types of drugs, such as Prozac and "anything else you could need."

What do you think of the vaping issue? Do you think it should be regulated more than it is?
link_name: TEMECULA: Rep. Hunter gets mixed reviews for vaping during hearing

Students at Moreno Valley's oldest school will be among the first to benefit from a 2014 bond measure as district officials gear up to start work next month on a new Edgemont Elementary School campus.

As part of the $30 million project, the Moreno Valley Unified School District plans to demolish the existing buildings and build a brand-new campus at the 9.5 acre site on the west side of town.

Taco Bell plans to unveil a new mystery mash-up item during its first-quarter Super Bowl 50 ad. But fans who pre-order the item this week can pick up Saturday -- a day before its official unveiling. status_message:
As Riverside City College prepares to celebrate its 100th anniversary, the college is putting the finishing touches on projects that will give it a major presence downtown.

A state-of-the-art concert hall and a culinary school featuring a restaurant open to the public are the highlights of Riverside Community College District's Centennial Plaza, which is set to open March 13, when the college is commemorating its centennial.

What do you think of the new complex? Will it be a good addition to the downtown area?

status_message:
Tiffany "Timebomb" Van Soest added another world title strap to her growing collection Friday night with a unanimous-decision victory over Ashley Nichols for the vacant Lion Fight super bantamweight belt at Lion Fight 27 at Pechanga Resort and Casino.

This is the second world title for the Riverside Poly graduate.

status_message:
Inland Barbie fans are split on the dolls' new looks. Layla Michelle Subhani, who starved herself in high school to attain Barbies' looks, applauded the move. Nadia Lee, 64, says Barbie was a fairy-tale figure. "People my age are used to the old one," she said. "I don't know. If the dolls have got nice clothes, it doesn't matter."

Share your thoughts.

status_message:
Riverside library trustees voted 5-3 to recommend to the City Council that the downtown bus station on University Avenue should become the new site of the main library. The bus station site won out over multiple other options discussed -- including a Chestnut Street site that city staff recommended -- because it is bigger and more prominent than the other options, it remains close to downtown and it is large enough to potentially include mixed-use development in the future.

Do you think that will be a good site? If not, what option would you prefer?
link_name: RIVERSIDE: Bus station site proposed for main library

Recent snowfall has added a decorative cap to Inland mountains, seen in this photo taken from Riverside's Sycamore Canyon on Monday. More importantly, this winter's El Nino storms have been dumping more snow than average in the northern Sierra mountains that are the linchpin in California's water system.

status_message:
Is it safe for children to play on fields made of ground-up old tires? Media reports suggest playing on such fields is linked with cancer. California scientists will study the question and lawmakers are pushing a federal effort. The state group will first meet Feb. 8; the study is expected to be complete by June 2018.

What do you think?
Find out more about the debate here: http://www.pe.com/articles/rubber-792621-health-california.html

status_message: "We finally got a team," said 83-year-old Rosey Grier, the last surviving member of the Rams' famed Fearsome Foursome. "Now, all we have to do is support the team and do our part being former Rams." Grier and nearly a dozen other ex-L.A. Rams gathered at the Citadel Outlets on Sunday afternoon for a "Welcome Home Rams" party and charity fundraiser, hosted by longtime Riverside resident and former Rams defensive back Kermit Alexander and his wife, Tami.

status_message:
Urban food halls like L.A.'s Grand Central Market or the newer Anaheim Packing House have been a draw for diners who like a variety of food choices clustered in one place.

Riverside is poised to jump on the trend when it opens Mess Hall on Market, a downtown restaurant space down the block from the Fox theater that will house up to 15 vendors such as creative chefs, coffee and dessert stalls and a wine bar.

It's still just a concept, but developer Jerry Tessier, who is negotiating with the city to build the project, has a clear idea of how he wants it to take shape.

What do you think of this idea? What would you do to help the downtown area at night or after big shows at the Fox?

Zika virus is the latest mosquito-borne disease Inland officials are concerned about. Though the risk of infection in the region is low, authorities are concerned because the type of mosquito that can carry the virus has been found in Riverside and San Bernardino counties.

status_message:
The filing of $58 million in claims by survivors of a man slain in the San Bernardino terrorist massacre is likely just the first step in a lengthy, complex series of legal actions that could land in a courtroom.

Renee Wetzel, widow of shooting victim Michael Wetzel, and her three minor children seek that amount from San Bernardino County and its Department of Health Services, where Wetzel worked.

There also have been claims against the city of San Bernardino, including one for $3,000 in damages to resident Isabel Serrano's parked truck that she claimed was riddled by gunfire during the police shootout that killed the two terrorists.
link_name: SAN BERNARDINO SHOOTING: Claim is just first step in long process

"How do you find the strength to go on? What do you do when your heart has been broken in a thousand pieces?" Saddleback Church Pastor Rick Warren asked an arena full of San Bernardino County employees gathered to mourn their fallen colleagues. "You don't get over it. You get through it." status_message: Inland Regional Center employees returned to their office this morning for the first time since the mass shooting. The building where the attack took place, however, remains closed indefinitely. The center has received an outpouring of support in the past month, the executive director said. "This has shown me that our community stands strong during a crisis."
link_name: SAN BERNARDINO SHOOTING: Inland Regional Center reopens a month after attack

Your cable bill is going up. Again.

While facing a growing number of consumers who drop pay-TV for cheaper online alternatives, Time Warner Cable Inc., Comcast Corp., Dish Network Corp. and AT&T Inc. are all planning to increase their prices early next year -- at the risk of turning off more subscribers fed up with the rising cost of television.

How much are you paying now? At what cost will it not become worth it anymore?

The operators of a wastewater treatment plant in Eastvale said this week they have made progress in controlling noxious fumes that triggered more than 200 complaints to air quality officials earlier this year. 
 
"We are making a constant and steady effort to control odors," said Jeffrey Sims, administrator of the Western Riverside County Regional Wastewater Authority, the joint powers authority that operates the River Road sewage treatment plant.
link_name: EASTVALE: Sewer plant operators make progress on odor controls

status_message:
Members of the Islamic movement, the Ahmadiyya, hope to counter anti-Muslim sentiment by showcasing their faith at an Inland conference this weekend.
 
Organizers said they adjusted the theme of their annual event following the Dec. 2 San Bernardino mass shooting carried out by Syed Rizwan Farook, and his wife, Tashfeen Malik. Authorities have said the couple were radicalized Muslims who pledged allegiance to ISIS before the attacks.
 
San Bernardino Police Chief Jarrod Burguan will be honored at the Ahmadiyya Muslim conference.
link_name: SAN BERNARDINO SHOOTING: Islamic group to honor police chief

status_message:
Oscar-nominated actor Robert Downey Jr., once known more for his legal troubles and struggles with drug addiction, was among 91 former criminals who received pardons announced by Gov. Jerry Brown's office Thursday Dec. 24.

Five people who were convicted in Riverside and San Bernardino counties also were pardoned in the governor's annual holiday tradition. The pardons were for convictions dating back to 2001 or longer.
link_name: ROBERT DOWNEY JR.: Actor pardoned by Jerry Brown for drug-related offenses

status_message:
A local atheists group has erected a holiday display at the northwest corner of Temecula's Duck Pond Park, public land that for years has been home to a menorah, a nativity scene and Christmas tree during the holiday season.

The first-time display, which was put up by the Temecula Valley Atheists, is a 10-foot-high present emblazoned with the message: "Our hope for the holidays/peace on earth."
link_name: TEMECULA: Atheists sponsor holiday display at Duck Pond

After visiting with grieving families from the San Bernardino shooting for nearly three hours Friday, Dec. 19, President Barack Obama is poised to use executive action to enact tougher gun control laws.
 
Relatives of the 14 killed in the terror attack at the Inland Regional Center recounted their meeting with the president and first lady Michelle Obama, who took time to meet with each family individually.
 
They said the president seemed to genuinely care about what they were saying and was determined to take action to prevent future attacks.

status_message:
BREAKING NEWS: Enrique Marquez, the former neighbor and close friend of San Bernardino shooter Syed Rizwan Farook, has been charged with conspiring with Farook in 2011 and 2012 to support terrorists and plotting attacks on Riverside City College and the 91 freeway. He also was charged with illegally purchasing the rifles used in the fatal Dec. 2 attack -- although prosecutors say there is no evidence he participated in or had advanced knowledge of that shooting -- and with immigration fraud for allegedly entering into a "sham marriage" with a Russian woman whose sister was married to Farook's brother.

This story is developing. Check back at the link below for updates.

status_message:
As a Peace Corps volunteer, expert in global health and the mother of a 7-year-old boy, Anita Ashok Datar devoted her life to caring for and helping others, her family said.
 
Datar, of Takoma Park, Maryland, was one of at least 20 people killed in Friday's terror attack on a hotel in Mali, the State Department confirmed in a statement.
 
No other U.S. citizens were believed to have died in the attack, carried out by heavily armed Islamic extremists at a Radisson hotel in the Malian capital of Bamako.
link_name: MALI: American killed worked to improve global health

link_name: RONDA ROUSEY: Roughneck, role model or both? Inland girls weigh in

status_message:
Five years ago  Nov. 7, 2010  Riverside police Officer Ryan Bonaminio was killed in the line of duty. Bonaminio, 27, a four-year Riverside police officer and Army veteran, was shot to death while trying to capture a suspect in a hit-and-run collision who fled on foot into Fairmount Park.
 
Earl Ellis Green hit Bonaminio with a metal pipe when the officer slipped and fell while giving chase, and then shot him. Green, a career criminal, was convicted of murder and sentenced to death, a penalty yet to be carried out.
 
In the years since the officer's murder, there have been stories of sadness and joy within the story. Here are some of them.
link_name: REMEMBERING RYAN BONAMINIO: To the day, tragedy yields stories of tribute, joy

status_message:
An art exhibition of contemporary abstract icons juxtaposes the secular and the sacred through an unusual partnership between the Riverside Art Museum and All Saints' Episcopal Church.

The church and museum will each showcase about half of the dramatic works in the 100-piece exhibition of internationally acclaimed abstract expressionist, Ludmila Pawlowska.

The exhibition, "Icons in Transformation," includes 12 large sculptural pieces and 15 traditional Russian icons from a monastery that inspired Pawlowska. The exhibit opens in Riverside on Friday, Oct. 30, and will run through Jan. 15.
link_name: RIVERSIDE: No separation of church and art

status_message:
One fad in the Inland area that is gaining momentum is the ability to drink alcohol as you watch the latest blockbuster in theaters. 

The Tristone Cinemas Jurupa 14 started selling beer and wine in select theaters in 2013. Now the AMC Theatres location in Riverside has a full bar menu including cocktails. Other Inland theaters are working on plans to follow suit.

Have you indulged in a cocktail while relaxing at a good movie at either theater? Will options such as these make you more likely to visit a movie theater? Staff writer Timothy Guy would love to talk with you. Contact him at 951-368-9342 or tguy@pe.com.

status_message: Corona commuters, good news: Transportation officials say you can expect East Grand Boulevard to be open by 5 a.m. Monday. Engineers say it is safe for traffic to travel under an onramp bridge that partially collapsed during construction work late Friday, injuring nine workers. The freeway itself has remained open, and construction will resume Monday as well.
link_name: CORONA: Road beneath partially collapsed freeway bridge to reopen Monday

status_message:
California ended its most recent fiscal year having left $43 million in fire-prevention funds in the bank -- angering some Inland residents and officials who oppose a fee on rural property owners adopted in 2011 to raise funds for prevention. Cal Fire says it's trying to create a "prudent reserve," but critics accuse the state agency of "hoarding," possibly in case it loses a lawsuit over the fee's legality.

Would you like to see that money saved or spent?
link_name: WILDFIRES: Fire prevention fund still has $43 million

status_message: A firefighter who was beaten by shooting spree suspect James Paul Diaz Jr. says he warned prosecutors in 2014 that Diaz would eventually kill someone. A woman killed in the partial collapse Monday of the Big Four Ice Caves in Washington's Cascade Range has been identified as Anna L. Santana, 34, of Moreno Valley.

Her body, which was at the back of the cave covered by snow and ice, was removed Tuesday despite treacherous conditions, the Snohomish County Sheriff's Office said.

status_message:
A defunct iron ore mine near Joshua Tree National Park, a site once considered for the world's largest landfill, has sold for $25 million to a company that wants to develop a hydroelectric project there.

The $1.4 billion Eagle Mountain Pumped Storage Project near Desert Center, north of Interstate 10, would draw water from three wells on surrounding property and pump it 15 miles to lined reservoirs in two vacant pits at the old Kaiser Steel mine.
link_name: JOSHUA TREE: Plan aims to turn desert water to electricity

Ramos refutes the allegations and says he welcomes a probe. A special meeting is set Wednesday to discuss the matter.

What do you think?

Whiskers Beach -- an anglers haven on the northeast shore of Lake Elsinore -- is poised for a quarter-million upgrade, including a drainage system, walkways and a parking lot paved with an all-weather surface. The council will decide on the project later today.

Share your thoughts on the beach. If you've never been, share your favorite fishing spots.

status_message:
Fans of Huell Howser may remember him excitedly calling out, "Louie, take a look at this!" Louie was cameraman Luis Fuerte, who is co-writing a book on his 19 years working with Howser. PE columnist: Cassie MacDuff got a sneak peak at the manuscript, which is being shopped around to publishers.

Find out more here: http://x.pe.com/1eCFQYQ Would you read the book?

status_message:
Happy Father's Day to all the dads out there! We hope you enjoy this story about one Inland dad who juggles several jobs -- from teaching high school math to serving up tacos -- to provide for his family.

Tell us in comments what your dad has done for your family that makes you proud!
link_name: SAN BERNARDINO: For this dad, several jobs are all in a day's work

status_message:
Seventeen years after it was first turned on, a wastewater treatment plant in Eastvale is being upgraded and enlarged, a multimillion-dollar project that will include the installation of systems to control odors emanating from the facility.

Plant operators are hopeful the project will put an end to a bitter and stinky dispute with their closest neighbors over bad odors.

What do you think?
link_name: EASTVALE: Homeowners want stinky issue to go away

By Thursday night, the Lake fire had grown to 10,000 acres and more than 400 people had been evacuated. The blaze had exploded 3 a.m. Thursday, and fire officials worried similar conditions would appear Friday morning.

For more fire coverage -- including evacuation centers and what experts make of the blaze -- click here: http://x.pe.com/1N8m5Uh

Each year, the Fourth of July holiday brings out pyrotechnic enthusiasts who light up the local skies with illegal fireworks. Some Inland Empire residents say the barrage of activity makes their neighborhoods sound like a war zone. 

We'd like to know what you think. If you'd like to speak to a reporter on the issue, contact staff writer Mark Muckenfuss at mmuckenfuss@pe.com or 951-368-9595.

The proposed $330.35 million Indio jail expansion that would add 1,200 beds to the chronically crowded jail system is expected to be approved Tuesday by the Riverside County Board of Supervisors.  Officials hope the expansion can be finished by late 2017.

status_message:
If Joe Baca runs for public office again, it won't be as a Democrat. The 68-year-old former Inland congressman switched his party registration from Democrat to Republican earlier this month. "I've always been very conservative," he says.

What do you think of Baca's switch?
Read the complete story here: http://x.pe.com/1JS0aAE

A Temecula site that has for years been eyed by water-park developers is now being looked at for a family-friendly golf attraction. A plan for a water park at Dendy Parkway and Diaz Road fell through earlier this year.

status_message:
Riverside County officials are concerned with what they say is a growing trend in delays offloading ambulance patients. Until the patient is transferred to the hospital's care, the paramedics can't leave. A county survey found while some hospitals are better than others, delays of over an hour aren't uncommon -- and there were even instances of waits up to eight hours.

Have you ever experienced a long delay? What do you think should be done?
link_name: RIVERSIDE COUNTY: Hospitals keep patients, ambulances waiting, survey finds

Recall attempts against three Moreno Valley City Council members appear to be a proxy for a battle on the proposed World Logistics Center mega warehouse project. While Yxstian Gutierrez was targeted by opponents of the center, LaDonna Jempson and George Price were targeted by warehouse supporters.

status_message:
In the early 2000s, there was a movement away from choosing a single valedictorian per high school. Educators cited bitter and harmful competition and arbitrary criteria. But now the pendulum is swinging the other way -- to the delight of certain motivated and high-achieving students. "I just thought like when you have so many, it kind of just takes away from the prestige," said this year's solo valedictorian at Temescal Canyon High School.

Do you think multiple valedictorians or just one is a better system? Why?
link_name: EDUCATION: Single valedictorians are back in vogue

"You've all been taken advantage of by a for-profit college," Rep. Mark Takano said yesterday at a clinic he organized for former students of Everett College, whose owner closed down last month. Takano also said that "we need to get Wall Street out of education" and has introduced legislation designed to protect students from predatory and fraudulent practices by for-profit colleges.

Do you think for-profit colleges are doing more harm or good?

status_message:
Until this weekend, Lake Hemet was a place to fish or kayak, but swimming was forbidden in the reservoir in the San Jacinto Mountains. But now, not only is swimming allowed in limited areas, but there's also an inflatable play attraction called Splash Island II. PE columnist: Bob Pratte has the details.

Do you want to visit?
link_name: BOB PRATTE: At long last, go for a swim this summer at Lake Hemet

status_message:
As the hot season approaches, Inland parks usually start turning on splash pads to give kids a place to have some fun and stay cool. But this year, some cities will be keeping them off, or at least reducing their hours, because of the drought. We talked to city officials throughout the Inland area to find out who's doing what: http://x.pe.com/1F9SynS

Would you be disappointed if your local splash pad stays dry this summer?
link_name: DROUGHT: Parks cutting wet play to save water

status_message:
The fate of two endangered plants that grow in the hills near Lake Elsinore is uncertain, despite the fact that they're in a wildlife habitat preserve. At the behest of Supervisor Kevin Jeffries, county officials are negotiating to swap two parcels of land where the endangered plants grow with developers, who plan to build more than 1,000 houses on a neighboring property.

Read more about the situation here: http://x.pe.com/1Gx9Foe. Do you think the land swap would be a good thing?
link_name: RIVERSIDE COUNTY: Endangered plants face uncertain future

status_message: Pearl Hughton of Victorville, left, talks with daughter-in-law Jade Hughton of Hesperia as they visit the grave of Jade's mother, Sybil Bunda, at Riverside National Cemetery on Saturday, May 23. As Cal State San Bernardino works to improve its on-campus housing opportunities, administrators and developers hope that a new master-planned community of furnished townhouses with lavish amenities -- flat-screen TVs, luxury kitchens, walk-in closets -- will be a good way to attract students from other countries, states and regions of California.

The first McDonald's restaurant in San Bernardino opened 75 years ago Friday -- as a barbecue joint. It was a teen-friendly hot spot, but the McDonald brothers wanted a family place. So, in 1948 the brothers retooled the stand -- and a legend was born.

Two major surveys from the Pew Research Center released this week show how quickly our cultural landscape is shifting.

One shows that the percentage of adults in the U.S. -- and in the Inland area -- who identify as Christian has declined sharply since 2007: http://x.pe.com/1E6cPZT

The other found that a rising share of Latinos in the U.S. speak proficient English and a declining number speak Spanish at home: http://x.pe.com/1HhxbH8

Before you do something like install a water heater or repair a roof, a county building inspector has to sign off. In a county the size of San Bernardino County -- more than 20,000 square miles -- that's a lot of travel. A new app seeks to ease the process.

Here's how the app works: http://x.pe.com/1F5JbI0 If the pilot program goes well, would you like to see its use expanded?

status_message: The San Bernardino County Sheriff's Department has released the names of eight deputies, a detective and a sergeant involved in last month's arrest -- caught on video by a news helicopter -- in which an Apple Valley suspect was punched and kicked as he laid on the ground. status_message:
Riverside County's IT network is vulnerable to cyber attacks that could put billions of dollars, Social Security numbers and other sensitive data at risk, according to a recently released audit. "We should be all over the security on this. This is not small-time,"  Auditor-Controller Paul Angulo said.

But county officials downplayed Angulo's concerns, with the county CEO saying the auditor "prepares many reports. We read them. We have found it is best to have security experts handle security."

Read more: http://x.pe.com/1ydMNFL Does the report worry you, or are you reassured by county officials' response?
link_name: RIVERSIDE COUNTY: Data vulnerable to cyber theft, auditor says

status_message: It's election day - Have you voted yet? Send your "I voted" selfie to photo@pe.com
link_name: The Press-Enterprise's cover photo

status_message:
You know it's Election Day, right? (It'd be hard not to.) The latest Field Poll predicted that only 46 percent of California's registered voters would actually vote, which would be a record low. So whatever color your political stripes are, if you're registered to vote, please turn out today. There are a slew of local, statewide and national contests on your ballot. You've got until 8 p.m.

If you haven't been following the campaign, never fear. Head on over to www.pe.com, where you'll find links to all sorts of resources to help you learn about the candidates and issues.

Show off your civic pride by sending us a picture of you and your "I Voted" sticker (photo@pe.com; include your name and city of residence). 

And if you encounter any problems at the polls, let us know by emailing breakingnews@pe.com.
link_name: Timeline Photos

Our top breaking news stories so far today. 

Police are seeking the public's help finding a woman with a psychotic mental disorder (pictured) who "poses a threat to others and herself" after she went missing from a treatment facility in San Bernardino.

A bicyclist was killed this morning in Riverside, and the driver who police say collided with him was arrested on suspicion of prescription-drug DUI.

A man from Temecula attending college in South Dakota has been found dead inside a grain elevator on a farm there. 

Read these stories and more: http://www.pe.com/sections/news/breaking-news/ (or m.pe.com/Breaking%20News on a mobile device). And get more breaking news headlines throughout the day by following us on Titter @PEcom_news

status_message:
With the election less than a week away, the campaign news keeps on coming. A few highlights:

Spending on Measure L, a ballot issue regarding land use in the La Sierra area of Riverside, has risen into the seven figures -- almost all from proponents of the measure.

Former President Bill Clinton celebrated two Inland congressional candidates at a rally yesterday in Oxnard.

And a campaign mailer funded by a Moreno Valley warehouse developer attempts to link a City Council candidate with two recently convicted local politicians.

Read these stories and more: 
http://www.pe.com/sections/news/politics/

Get ready to stay up late Monday night. If the sky is clear just after midnight (officially Tuesday, April 15) Pacific time, a full moon with a reddish tinge will shine above Southern California, the first of four total lunar eclipses in the next 17 months.

David Reaver, 75, is considered by some to be the "godfather" of K-9 training. Since 1975, he has trained thousands of K-9s at his seven-acre property in Jurupa Valley, and has provided dogs for law enforcement agencies in the Inland area and across the western U.S.

Construction has begun on a 400-home tract in Jurupa Valley that was approved before the recession hit -- and before Jurupa Valley was a city. Laws passed during the recession, when many developers had to suspend work, bar governmental agencies from rescinding approvals, a city official said.

status_message:
Steven Erdodi is paying his penance. In 2010, he shared drugs with a friend at a party -- and the next morning, she never woke up. "I made it all the way through high school without drugs and now here I am. Her parents lost a daughter. Her sisters lost a sister. I lost a great friend," Erdodi told students at his alma mater, Riverside's King High, in a presentation that is part of his probation terms.

This cautionary tale by PE Columnist: Dan Bernstein is one to share with the teenagers and young adults you know. Read it here: http://x.pe.com/1lw75Wl

status_message:
Union Pacific's Big Boy, a 1941 steam locomotive that is among the largest ever built, has embarked on an epic journey that many rail fans dreamed of but never truly thought would come to pass.

On the night of Jan. 26, it will roll off the Pomona fairgrounds and onto the national rail system for the first time in more than 50 years. That will begin its journey  under tow  to Union Pacific's Colton yard. In the spring, it will be towed north to Cheyenne, Wyo., where it will undergo a four- to five-year restoration that will return it to operation as a rolling museum.

Read this great story about the journey of Engine 4014, and see more photos, here: http://x.pe.com/1dVUXHu

A nonprofit organization called Angel Faces reaches out to girls who've endured this heartbreak, teaching them special makeup techniques, helping them communicate with people frightened by their injuries and restoring their self-esteem and, often, their place in their families and communities. Reporter Peter Fischetti, photographer David Bauman and videographer Angel Ortiz teamed up for this moving PE.com special report. http://blog.pe.com/2013/07/26/angel-faces/


http://blog.pe.com/2013/07/26/angel-faces/

status_message:
The U.S. Supreme Court Tuesday, March 26, will hear oral arguments on the constitutionality of Prop. 8, which banned same-sex marriage in California.

Thousands are expected at the "March for Marriage" in Washington, D.C., on Tuesday to support Prop. 8 and oppose same-sex marriage.

Inland Empire supporters of same-sex marriage are holding vigils in Riverside and Rancho Cucamonga on March 25, and in Redlands on March 27.

If you're planning to attend any of these events, or know of other events that Inland residents are attending, please contact reporter David Olson at dolson@pe.com.

status_message: (VIDEO) An 18-month-old child was killed early Tuesday afternoon, Oct. 2, in what appears to be a tragic accident involving family members. The child, whose name and sex have not been released, and its mother were being dropped off at the complex in the 2500 block of Grambling Way just north of Amethyst Street, said Riverside police Lt. Eric Charrette. The mother took the child out of the vehicle, still in its child-restraint seat, and set it on the ground. As she closed the door, she was unaware that the child had gotten out of the seat and crawled in front of the wheel of the SUV. The driver, apparently another family member, drove away, running over the child. Riverside Fire Department paramedics arrived and pronounced the child dead.
link_name: Child crawls under car, is hit, killed

Seeing pink?  We've switched on the pink in support of Breast Cancer Awareness Month. For the second year, The Press-Enterprise will print a special "pink edition" on Sunday. You can get your keepsake copy of the special edition at our usual retail outlets. 

The Press-Enterprise is donating 10 percent of proceeds from advertising in the print "pink edition" to help find a cure. You will find stories in print and online that put a spotlight on what people in Inland Southern California are doing to combat breast cancer. 

We hope you will join us in the fight against this disease and recognizing the courage and determination exhibited by those with breast cancer.

status_message: Recent reports from the Riverside County Grand Jury uncovered allegations of workplace bullying in county government. status_message:
A REQUEST FROM PE REPORTER DAVID OLSON:

Are you planning to go to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art Sunday to view the opening of "Levitated Mass," the exhibit starring a 340-ton boulder from a Jurupa Valley quarry?

I'm going to be there and I'll be looking for Inland residents to interview. 

Museum admission is free to residents of the 73 ZIP codes the giant rock traveled through on its 105-mile journey from the quarry to the museum, where it arrived March 10. Here's a list of the ZIP codes, many of which are in the Inland area: www.lacma.org/sites/default/files/ZipCodeOffer2.pdf 

Please email me at dolson@pe.com if you are planning to be there Sunday -- or even if you may go later in the week (admission is free through July 1).

And if you're someone who still can't understand why so many people are so excited about a big rock, I'd like to hear from you as well.

Thanks a lot.

David
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: A recent poll in Arizona, a state known for its assertive efforts to halt illegal immigration, is evidence of how many Americans have more nuanced beliefs on illegal immigration than the emotional debate on the issue would indicate, says Multicultural Empire blogger David Olson. Nearly three-quarters percent of Arizonans support the Dream Act. That is the proposal that would allow many undocumented immigrants who graduate from college or serve in the military to eventually become citizens. The art of managing the elements was almost as important as the ability to drive fast and turn left smoothly yesterday at The Track Formerly Known As California Speedway, according to PE columnist Jim Alexander.

More from Jim: "Oh, by the way, the official NASCAR attendance estimate -- the organization and its tracks never give precise figures -- was 90,000, which would suggest 75,000 in the grandstand. Not sure I buy that. My eyeball estimate at the start of the race said 60,000 in the grandstand, which seats 92,000 at full capacity but had 14 sections (between 8,000 and 9,000 seats) covered by tarps.

Bottom line: The non-sellout streak for NASCAR Cup races is 16. But let's just say Fontana has plenty of company on the circuit these days when it comes to empty seats."

http://www.pe.com/sports/sports-columns/jim-alexander-headlines/20120325-alexander-drivers-crews-had-an-eye-on-the-doppler.ece

status_message:
After "I Love Lucy" went off the air and Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz divorced, Arnaz decamped to Corona in 1960 where he operated a thoroughbred horse breeding ranch. The 45-acre Corona Breeding Farm, near Lincoln Avenue and West Rincon Street, is long gone. But more than 50 years later, the 4,400-square-foot Spanish-style ranch house that Arnaz helped design still exists. If all goes as planned, the structure soon could become a meeting and event venue in Eastvale. Come take a peek inside Desi's old pad.

http://www.pe.com/local-news/riverside-county/corona/corona-headlines-index/20120324-eastvale-a-rebirth-for-the-desi-arnaz-house.ece

When two long-time clients at her San Bernardino salon were diagnosed with cancer, Karen Brown realized that she couldn't make her store bought wigs look right for them. So she started studying. After a few years, she had a new mission. "As women, when we start to lose our hair, we lose our identity," Brown said. "I'm trying to encourage and support women who are hurting with a safe place for them to go and get some tools and information."

http://www.pe.com/local-news/san-bernardino-county/san-bernardino-county-headlines-index/20120225-redlands-stylist-gives-back-the-identity-illness-took.ece

status_message:
Fifty years ago, "West Side Story" won 10 Academy Awards, including the Oscar for Best Picture. The modern-day retelling of "Romeo and Juliet" that debuted as a Broadway musical five years earlier is based in part on a fictional turf war between Puerto Rican and white street gangs on the upper west side of Manhattan. But few know that the beloved musical that is a staple of famous theaters and high school stages likely never would have existed but for a real-life gang fight on the west side of  San Bernardino. Do you have memories to share about that incident? 

http://www.pe.com/local-news/san-bernardino-county/san-bernardino-county-headlines-index/20120226-san-bernardino-gang-fight-sparked-west-side-story.ece

status_message:
Meet our new pet. We call him "Rusty."

Seriously, this mammoth critter is on the move. He and other sheet-metal residents of Perris Jurassic Park were loaded onto trailers for the 39-mile trip to their new home at the Vail Lake Resort this week.

The approximately 300 sculptures, ranging from ants a few inches high to the 20-foot-high T-Rex that overlooks the interstate, are being moved to an arts center east of Temecula.

Check out David Bauman's whimsical images of the moving monsters on PE.com. Do you have any stories to share about the Park? How about your own photos to share?

http://www.pe.com/photos/photos-news/20120222-perris-perris-jurassic-park-moving-to-new-location.ece

This sub has been rising for years!
Sub Station, an institution for UC Riverside, is marking 40 years of serving students Feb. 24-25. It will have an anniversary-themed sandwich special on those two days: buy one at 2012 prices and get a second at 1972 prices. Share your memories of Sub Station with us. Did it get you through mid-terms and finals? Did you have good times there with your friends? Did you work the counter?

Stars including Stevie Wonder and Christina Aguilera will perform as friends, family and the music industry say farewell to R&B icon Etta James at a private ceremony this morning. status_message:
What's your favorite Inland Southern California myth? 

PE reporter Tim Guy is writing a story about the guys from "Mythbusters" coming to the Fox. He's looking for Inland "myths" ripe for the debunking.
For example: There is a intricate, full navigable series of tunnels beneath the city of Riverside. True or false?
 
If you have heard any whoppers -- or geniunely true facts -- please pass along your "myths" to us here.

Many Inland churches will be overflowing on Saturday night and Sunday with people who typically only attend services on Christmas Eve (or Christmas Day) and Easter. If you are one of those folks who usually only attend church on Christmas and/or Easter, please contact reporter David Olson at 951-368-9462 or dolson@pe.com.

READER SUBMITTED PHOTO:

A family in Corona sent this in:
We are trapped in our house due to tumleweeds invasion.  No one from county code enforcement and weed abatement will help.  

Trapped

Near praed and mccallister!  Send reporter!
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
READER SUBMITTED PHOTO:

At 4am we woke up to 2 trampolines swirling around our backyard, please note we only own 1 trampoline! The other came from our neighbors house about 1000 feet+ away! It jumped 4 fences and backyards to get into ours! At one point as we were trying to corral the trampolines they both started tumbling towards us and we went running for our safety, pretty scary!

The Hoekstra Family

status_message:
Marine recruiter, would-be recruits accused of rape

A U.S. Marine Corps recruiter drove two would-be recruits to Hemet to have sex with a 14-year-old girl, then planned to force her to work as a prostitute, authorities said.

Staff Sgt. Bryan Damone Cunningham, 33, is charged with seven felonies, including attempted pimping and kidnapping with intent to rape.

status_message:
Riverside County sheriff bucks cuts, raises pay

Days after Sheriff Stanley Sniff told Riverside County supervisors he could not afford any cuts to his department without taking deputies from streets and jails, he raised the six-figure salary of one chief deputy by 19 percent, another by 11 percent and a third by almost 6 percent.
